• Open

    From Peak Oil to Peak Energy? ... and Why It Matters
    WASHINGTON DC, Dec 04 (IPS) - The International Energy Agency now projects oil, gas, and coal use will all peak this decade. This constitutes a dramatic shift from the last 150 years when the thirst for fossil fuels persistently rose. But now this growth is nearing its end sooner than many expected, driven in part by a surge in renewables. Read the full story, “From Peak Oil to Peak Energy? ... and Why It Matters”, on globalissues.org →  ( 5 min )

The comments came a day after the breakdown in negotiations over hostage and prisoner releases led to the resumption of the Israel-Hamas war. Austin told an audience at the Reagan National Defense Forum that if Israel doesn’t do everything possible to protect civilians, it might help “drive [Palestinians] into the arms of the enemy,” and would “replace a tactical victory with a strategic defeat.”   Read more ....   WNU Editor: Reaction to Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin's remarks has been swift ....     The Hill: White House warns it will run out of money for Ukraine unless Congress acts by end of year   The White House sounded the alarm Monday that it will run out of money to provide weapons to Ukraine in its fight against Russia without congressional action by the end of the year.  In a letter to congressional leaders, Office of Management and Budget Director Shalanda Young wrote the government is “out of money—and nearly out of time” to continue giving aid to Ukraine.The White House pleaded with Congress to act on a supplemental funding request first submitted in October, arguing it is of critical importance to U.S. national security.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: The mood in Ukraine has definitely changed in the past few weeks.     Venezuelans Vote Overwhelmingly To Seize Guyana's Oil Rich Region
    Reuters: Venezuelan voters reject ICJ jurisdiction over dispute with Guyana  CARACAS (Reuters) - Voters in Venezuela rejected in a Sunday referendum the International Court of Justice's jurisdiction over the country's long-running territorial dispute with neighboring Guyana and backed the creation of a new state in the Esequibo region.  The court has barred Venezuela from taking any action that would change the status quo in the area, but President Nicolas Maduro's government went ahead with a five-question "consultative" referendum. All questions passed with more than 95% approval, according the electoral authority.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: Venezuelan President Maduro is unpredictable.     Pacific Leaders Announce Largest Conservation Effort in History
    DUBAI, Dec 04 (IPS) - Pacific people live at the nexus of oceans, climate, and food systems, and the interaction of climate and ocean is raising sea temperatures and threatening habitats and resources vital to the region’s sustenance, Palau’s President Surangel Whipps, Jr., said at the launch of an effort to protect and rejuvenate the region's ecosystems and empower communities through to the year 2050—in what is considered to be the biggest single conservation effort in history—Unlocking Blue Pacific Prosperity.     A Climate Scientist’s View of COP 28
    STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec 04 (IPS) - This year’s UN Climate Change Conference is taking place in Dubai from 30 November to 12 December. The so-called COP summits are organised every year and constitute a means for the global community to agree on ways to address the climate crisis, such as limiting global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, supporting vulnerable communities to adapt to the effects of climate change, and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.     Scientists uncover 'Lost City' beneath Atlantic Ocean
    Scientists have discovered the Lost City Hydrothermal Field, an otherworldly environment with towering structures and a thriving ecosystem. This hydrothermal field is located close to an underwater mountain west of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. It features creamy carbonate towers, some up to 60 meters tall. The Lost City is unique because it has sustained its existence for at least 120,000 years and contains hydrocarbons formed on the deep seafloor....  ( 51 min )
    Alaska Airlines to acquire Hawaiian Airlines in $1.9 billion deal
    Alaska Airlines announces intent to purchase Hawaiian Airlines for $1.9 billion, awaiting regulatory approval. Merger would create nation's fifth-largest carrier, with combined fleet of 365 aircraft serving 138 destinations. Potential benefits include expanded connections to U.S., Asia, and the Pacific. Regulatory scrutiny expected due to reduced competition in Hawaii. Acquisition reflects industry trend of consolidation to navigate financial challenges.  ( 50 min )
    Pakistan's election body asks govt to deploy army on general election day
    Pakistan's Election Commission has asked the government to deploy regular army troops to ensure security during the general election scheduled for February 8, 2024. The commission stated that the provincial police force is insufficient, requiring at least 591,106 security personnel. There is a shortage of 277,558 police personnel in the provinces and federation. The demand for army deployment is not new in Pakistan. The caretaker Information Minister assured that the government will provide the necessary funds, as approved by the Cabinet, for the Election Commission's needs. Finance Secretary Imdadullah Bosal confirmed that the funds will be released within two days.  ( 52 min )
    EU states to start debating Ukraine membership talks on Tuesday

Hungary argues that Ukraine is not ready due to corruption and ongoing conflict. Hungary's concerns may complicate negotiations. Other EU countries seek to advance the prospects of Georgia and Bosnia in exchange for supporting Ukraine. EU aid to Hungary has been unlocked to sway Budapest's decision.  ( 55 min )
    Harvard accused of favouring Facebook by disinformation scholar
    Joan Donovan, a disinformation scholar, accuses Harvard University of infringing on her free speech by dismissing her, potentially to appease Facebook. Donovan's termination, allegedly linked to Harvard's $500 million pledge from Meta founder Mark Zuckerberg, is seen as compromising academic freedom and prioritizing the interests of the tech giant. Harvard denies Donovan's claims, asserting that she was a staff employee and offering her a part-time role, which she declined.  ( 52 min )
    Death toll from Tanzania landslides rises to 63
    Tanzanian Prime Minister Kassim Majaliwa pays tribute to the 63 people killed in landslides and flooding in Katesh. The toll is expected to rise. Torrential downpours caused the disaster, washing away vehicles and buildings. Rescue operations are underway with the help of the military. The floods exacerbate the humanitarian crisis in the region, which is recovering from a severe drought. The president has cut short her visit to Dubai for the COP28 climate talks.  ( 50 min )
    Putin blames Nord Stream blasts for disruption of Russia-Germany relations
    Putin discussed disrupted cooperation between Moscow and Berlin due to the blasts in September 2022 that affected the Nord Stream pipelines. He mentioned this during a ceremony in the Kremlin while accepting new foreign ambassadors. Putin emphasized that the current frozen state of relations is unprofitable for both countries, especially Germany. He highlighted that energy cooperation was disrupted by the sabotage on the Nord Stream pipelines. Russia has accused the United States, Britain, and Ukraine of the pipeline blasts, but they have all denied any involvement. Putin also expressed hope for improved relations between Moscow and London.  ( 48 min )
    Kenyan court suspends plan to privatise more state-owned firms
    A Kenyan court on Monday suspended a government plan to start a fresh privatisation drive under a modified law while it hears a challenge that an opposition party has brought against the sales. In late November the finance ministry said it would start the process of offering to sell its shareholding in 11 firms, including an oil pipeline, a textbook publisher and agribusiness firms. The 11 companies are among more than 35 companies that are lined up for sale, partly to help the government raise revenue in the face of growing debt repayments.  ( 47 min )
    Argentina's Milei picks former pro-Nazi youth for top legal post
    Argentina's president-elect Javier Milei appoints Rodolfo Barra, a former justice minister, as the attorney general of the treasury. Barra's appointment has sparked controversy due to his past involvement in an ultranationalist movement and anti-Semitism claims. The Argentine Forum Against Anti-Semitism and opposition politicians have protested against Barra's appointment, calling it a direct affront to the democratic and plural spirit of the country. Barra had previously apologized for his past behavior, but concerns remain about his suitability for the role.  ( 49 min )
    Israel, Palestinians accuse each other of 'genocide' at UN
    Israeli and Palestinian representatives at the UN Human Rights Council traded accusations of 'genocide' over the war in Gaza. Israel's war against Hamas and the resulting man-made catastrophe were discussed. The Israeli representative highlighted the genocidal ideology of Hamas and the online anti-Semitism faced by the Jewish people. The Palestinian representative emphasized the massive bombing campaign by Israel and called for early action under the genocide convention. Other Muslim countries accused Israel of incitement to genocide, and concerns were raised about the failure to prevent genocide and the repression of Palestinian voices online.  ( 55 min )
    Death toll from Tanzania landslides rises to 57
    Torrential downpours in Katesh, northern Tanzania, caused landslides and flooding, resulting in at least 57 deaths and many more trapped. President Samia Suluhu Hassan, who cut short her visit to Dubai for climate talks, confirmed the casualties. Regional commissioner Queen Sendiga initially reported 47 dead. The military is assisting with search and rescue operations as thick mud hampers efforts. The floods compound the humanitarian crisis in East Africa, which is recovering from a severe drought. Human-induced climate change is making extreme weather events more frequent and intense.  ( 52 min )
    Pakistan court summons Imran Khan, wife on December 6 in Al-Qadir case
    Pakistan anti-corruption court summons former PM Imran Khan and wife Bushra Bibi for the Al-Qadir Trust case. Non-bailable arrest warrants issued for six others, including Malik Riaz Hussain, in the Al-Qadir Trust corruption case. Judge orders Khan's production from Adiala Jail and directs Bibi to appear. Next hearing to be held at Adiala Jail. Charges allege Khan and Bibi obtained billions of rupees and land from Bahria Town Ltd to legalize Rs50 billion returned from the UK.  ( 49 min )
    Israel investigates possible trading knowledge ahead of October 7 Hamas attack
    Israeli authorities are investigating claims that some investors may have profited from Israeli securities by short-selling shares based on advance knowledge of a Hamas plan to attack Israel. Law professors Robert Jackson Jr and Joshua Mitts found significant short-selling of the MSCI Israel ETF and Israeli securities on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange leading up to the attacks. The matter is under investigation by the Israel Securities Authority and relevant parties. The researchers also discovered a sharp increase in trading of risky short-dated options on Israeli companies just before the attacks.  ( 54 min )
    Spanish media association files $598 million lawsuit against Facebook owner Meta
    At least 83 Spanish media outlets had filed a USD 598 million lawsuit against Meta platforms for unfair competition in the advertising market. The AMI newspaper filed a lawsuit with the media association. The newspapers said Meta's "massive" and "systematic" use of personal data from the users of its Facebook, Instagram, and Whatsapp platforms allows it to get an unfair advantage in designing and offering personalized ads that constitute unfair competition.  ( 46 min )
    Why many alums are making just $1 donations to Harvard
    Harvard University faces alumni dissatisfaction and a substantial decline in donations due to concerns over the handling of a campus crisis, including reports of antisemitism. The university's fundraising operation, which relies on volunteers, is struggling to assuage these concerns while maintaining financial support. The financial impact of this alumni revolt is uncertain, but it poses a reputational risk and could have a significant effect on Harvard's annual revenue.  ( 83 min )
    Jailed Nobel winner Mohammadi to continue protests, she says in smuggled letter
    Narges Mohammadi, the jailed Iranian Nobel Peace Prize winner, vows to continue her fight for human rights, even if it means risking her life. Currently serving multiple sentences in Tehran's Evin prison, she is accused of spreading propaganda against the Islamic Republic. Her imprisonment and psychological torture have not deterred her. She started a hunger strike to protest the prison's lack of medical care. In a letter smuggled out from prison, she expresses her longing for her children.  ( 49 min )

    UK military faces $22 billion equipment shortfall, watchdog says
    Britain's armed forces face a funding shortfall of 17 billion pounds over the next 10 years, the largest deficit since 2012. The budget for new weapons and equipment is estimated at 305.5 billion pounds for 2023-2033, 16.9 billion pounds over budget. Soaring costs in nuclear and naval programs, as well as high inflation, have pushed up the future budget. The Ministry of Defence's financial position has deteriorated. Russia's war in Ukraine has highlighted the need for extra military spending across Europe, with Britain as an important ally and provider of military equipment to Kyiv.  ( 51 min )
    Four killed in bomb attack on Catholic mass in Philippines
    A bomb attack on a Catholic mass in Marawi, Philippines, at Mindanao State University's gymnasium left at least four dead and dozens wounded. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the blast, which occurred during a morning service. The explosion was caused by an improvised explosive device. The university condemned the violence and suspended classes, while the city's mayor called for unity among Muslim and Christian communities.  ( 60 min )

    The Many Faces of the Monroe Doctrine
    In yet another curious twist in its long history, the Monroe Doctrine, which turned 200 on Saturday, is making an unexpected political comeback in the United States. “I think it’s as relevant today as it was the day it was written,” declared Rex Tillerson, Donald Trump’s first secretary of state, in Mexico City in 2018. More recently, contestants for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination have competed to lay claim to the doctrine.     Women, Peace, Security: Thinking Creatively to Pursue National Security through Gender Equality
    Twenty-three years after the U.N. Security Council passed the Women, Peace, and Security framework and six years after the United States became the only country to legislatively mandate its implementation, widespread misunderstanding remains about why it matters to national security. Contrary to what is sometimes heard among U.S. security practitioners in classrooms, conferences, and conversations, this is not a social justice program.     Emmanuel Macron calls on Albanese government to lift nuclear ban
    French President Emmanuel Macron has called on Australia to lift its nuclear ban after the government rejected a nuclear pledge at the COP28 summit. The declaration to triple nuclear energy capacity globally by 2050 was endorsed by more than 20 countries at the UN climate change conference. When asked by 17-year-old Nuclear for Australia founder Will Shackel about nuclear energy's role in global plans to decarbonise, President Macron said he hopes Australia will manage to lift the ban. “Nuclear energy is a source that is necessary to succeed for carbon neutrality in 2050,” Mr Macron said. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has criticised Labor, claiming the Albanese government has isolated itself from AUKUS allies by not endorsing the pledge.

    Pentagon Says A U.S. Navy Warship And Multiple Commercial Ships Have Come Under Attack In The Red Sea
    Daily Mail: The Pentagon says an American warship and multiple commercial vessels have come under attack in the Red Sea as Houthi rebels admit to launching strikes  * The attack on US maritime vessels potentially marks a major escalation in a series of attacks in the Middle East, linked to the ongoing Israel-Hamas war  * The Pentagon said on Sunday: 'We´re aware of reports regarding attacks on the USS Carney and commercial vessels in the Red Sea'  An American warship and multiple commercial ships came under attack in the Red Sea on Sunday, the Pentagon confirmed.  The attack on US maritime vessels potentially marks a major escalation in a series of attacks in the Middle East, linked to the ongoing Israel-Hamas war.  The Pentagon confirmed that Arleigh Burke-class guided-missile destroyer USS Carney - stationed in the waters between Africa and Asia - was under attack.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: The U.S. is now threatening a response ....     White House Says The U.S. Intelligence Community Was Not Aware Of Hamas’ Plan To Attack Israel
    WATCH: The U.S. intel community was not aware of Hamas' attack plan on Israel, NSC Coordinator for Strategic Communications John Kirby says. The New York Times reported that Israel received the attack plan over a year ago. pic.twitter.com/d1f3iBfLms — Meet the Press (@MeetThePress) December 3, 2023 Politico: US intelligence community was not aware of Hamas’ plan to attack Israel, Kirby confirms   His comments come after the New York Times reported that Israeli officials obtained the plans more than a year before the Oct. 7 attack occurred.  The U.S. intelligence community was not aware of Hamas’ plan to attack Israel, National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby said Sunday, after the New York Times reported last week that Israeli officials obtained the plans more than a year before the Oct. 7 attack occurred. “The intelligence community has indicated that they did not have access to this document,” Kirby told NBC’s Kristen Welker on “Meet the Press.” POLITICO reported Friday that there was no indication Israel had shared the blueprint for the attack with the United States.   Read more ....  White House Says The U.S. Intelligence Community Was Not Aware Of Hamas’ Plan To Attack Israel   Kirby: US intelligence had no knowledge of Hamas' attack plan documents -- Axios   Kirby says intelligence sources did not have access to Hamas’ attack plan after NYT report -- The Hill   US intel not aware of Hamas' plan for Oct. 7 attack on Israel, John Kirby says -- NYPost   U.S. Intelligence Community Was Not Aware of Hamas’ Plan to Attack Israel, Kirby Says -- National Review   U.S. Intelligence Was Not Aware of Hamas’ Plan to Attack Israel, National Security Council Spokesman Says -- Rolling Stone
    Israel’s Women Border Troops Say Their Warnings On Hamas Were Ignored
    IDF spotters working at the IDF base in Nahal Oz. Credit: IDF Spokesperson's Unit © סופק על ידי Haaretz.com  New York Times: Israel Knew Hamas’ Attack Plan More Than a Year Ago  TEL AVIV, Israel — Israeli officials obtained Hamas’ battle plan for the Oct. 7 terrorist attack more than a year before it happened, documents, emails and interviews show. But Israeli military and intelligence officials dismissed the plan as aspirational, considering it too difficult for Hamas to carry out.  The approximately 40-page document, which Israeli authorities code-named “Jericho Wall,” outlined, point by point, exactly the kind of devastating invasion that led to the deaths of about 1,200 people.  The translated document, which was reviewed by The New York Times, did not set a date for the attack, but described a methodical assault designed to overwhelm the fortifications around the Gaza Strip, take over Israeli cities and storm key military bases, including a division headquarters.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: Israeli and American officials are responding .... US and Israeli officials react to blockbuster report that Israel knew Hamas was planning attack (ABC News).   Israel’s Women Border Troops Say Their Warnings On Hamas Were Ignored  New York Times report says Israel knew about Hamas attack over a year in advance -- AP   IDF's elite intel unit saw signs Hamas preparing for attack: report -- Business Insider   Our warnings on Hamas were ignored, Israel’s women border troops say -- Politico.eu   The Women Soldiers Who Warned of a Pending Hamas Attack – and Were Ignored -- Haaretz   Female Officer Who Warned of Hamas Attack Months Ago Was Told ‘You’re Imagining Things’ by Commanders -- The Messenger   Israel 'knew about Hamas attack plans' over a year before it happened, New York Times reports -- SKY News   TV report claims Hamas produced Oct. 7-style infiltration plan in 2016; IDF got it in 2018 -- Times of Israel
    Will Israeli Intelligence And Military Leaders Be Held Accountable For Ignoring Intelligence Reports That Hamas Was Going To Attack On October 7th?
    Maj. Gen. Aharon Haliva, Israel’s military intelligence chief, at a command bunker in Tel Aviv, on May 20, 2021. It has been obvious to Israelis since the opening hours of the Oct. 7 attack that the assault was the result, at... (Dan Balilty / The New York Times)   Seattle Times/New York Times: Intelligence Errors Prompt Scrutiny of Israeli Generals, but Little Backlash  JERUSALEM — Israel’s military leadership faced heightened public scrutiny this past week after a string of damaging revelations in the Israeli media and The New York Times suggested that senior officers had ignored or dismissed intelligence reports about the likelihood of a major Hamas attack.  According to those reports, the Israeli military obtained a copy of a battle plan that Hamas ultimately used during its Oct. 7 attack on Israel, but officers wrongly judged that Hamas would be unable to carry it out. A commander also dismissed a subordinate’s warning in July that the group was running drills and building the capacity to set the plan in motion.  The news raised expectations among political commentators that, after the war ends, senior military and security chiefs will either resign or be fired over the intelligence failures.  Supporters of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seized upon the reports, using the allegations of military failure to deflect from accusations that Netanyahu was partly to blame for what many Israelis consider the country’s worst security failure in 50 years.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: Here is an easy prediction. No one in Israel is going to be held accountable for the October 7 intelligence failure until after the war is over .... US and Israeli officials react to blockbuster report that Israel knew Hamas was planning attack (ABC News).
    IDF Says It Has Uncovered 800 Hamas Tunnel Shafts Since The Start Of The War
    Reuters: Israel says it uncovered 800 shafts to Hamas tunnels below Gaza  JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Israeli forces have found 800 shafts leading to Hamas' vast subterranean network of tunnels and bunkers since a Gaza ground operation began on Oct 27, and have destroyed more than half of them, the military said on Sunday.  The Palestinian Islamist group said before the now eight-week-old war in the Gaza Strip that it had hundreds of kilometres of tunnels - a network comparable in size to the New York subway system - to protect and serve as operational bases.  That has made them prime targets for Israeli air strikes with penetrating munitions and army engineers using mapping robots and exploding gel that can be poured into the passages.  "The tunnel shafts were located in civilian areas, many of which were near or inside civilian buildings and structures, such as schools, kindergartens, mosques and playgrounds," the military said in a statement on Sunday.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: I do not know why the IDF is surprised. Hamas had years to prepare these tunnels .... IDF Faces 'Surprising' Strength and Sophistication of Hamas Tunnels in Gaza (Newsweek).  IDF Says It Has Uncovered 800 Hamas Tunnel Shafts Since The Start Of The War   IDF says 800 tunnels discovered in Gaza op, 500 destroyed or sealed -- Times of Israel IDF uncovers 800 Hamas tunnel shafts since start of war, destroys 500 -- Jerusalem Post   IDF Reports Locating Over 800 Hamas Tunnel Shafts In Gaza Schools And Mosques -- I24NEWS   IDF locates Hamas tunnel shaft in school courtyard -- FOX News
    Israel Is Using An AI Program Dubbed "The Gospel" To Select Targets In Gaza
    ‘To claim there’s precision and narrowness of force being exerted is not borne out by the facts,’ said one researcher. Photograph: Atef Safadi/EPA  The Guardian: ‘The Gospel’: how Israel uses AI to select bombing targets in Gaza   Concerns over data-driven ‘factory’ that significantly increases the number of targets for strikes in the Palestinian territory  Israel’s military has made no secret of the intensity of its bombardment of the Gaza Strip. In the early days of the offensive, the head of its air force spoke of relentless, “around the clock” airstrikes. His forces, he said, were only striking military targets, but he added: “We are not being surgical.”  There has, however, been relatively little attention paid to the methods used by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) to select targets in Gaza, and to the role artificial intelligence has played in their bombing campaign.  As Israel resumes its offensive after a seven-day ceasefire, there are mounting concerns about the IDF’s targeting approach in a war against Hamas that, according to the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza, has so far killed more than 15,000 people in the territory.   Read more ....   Update: Israeli AI ‘Assassination Factory’ Plays Central Role in the Gaza War (Antiwar.com)   WNU Editor: The software, computer networks, and the surveillance platforms that are being used to gather the intelligence that makes this possible must be incredibly complex and massive. But it explains why Israel is able to launch each day the large number of attacks that it claims are against Hamas targets.
    Are We On The Verge Of A U.S. -- Saudi Arabia Oil Supply War?
    Business Insider: Saudi Arabia could 'flush' the oil market with a flood of supply to regain control over prices in the face of rising US production, crude expert says  * Saudi Arabia may "flush" the market with a flood of supply that would sink prices, an expert said.  * That comes as OPEC+ concluded its latest meeting where members pledged voluntary production cuts without giving firm commitments.  * Meanwhile, US crude output has been on a tear this year, hitting new record highs.  Saudi Arabia may flood the market with more oil supplies, reversing its production curbs, as the world's top crude exporter tries to regain control of prices, an energy market veteran said.  That comes as OPEC+ concluded its latest meeting where members pledged voluntary production cuts without giving firm commitments, prompting oil prices to fall.  "We've more or less been saying potentially Saudi needs to just flush this thing out," Paul Sankey from Sankey Research told CNBC on Friday.   Read more ....   Update: Saudi Arabia is struggling to boost oil prices, raising possibility of supply war with U.S.   WNU Editor: As oil consumers we are all lucky that high oil prices has resulted in this .... Surging U.S. Oil Production Brings Down Prices and Raises Climate Fears (DNYUZ/New York Times).
    Has The Decline Of US Power Been Greatly Exaggerated?
    Tom Stevenson, The Guardian: America’s undying empire: why the decline of US power has been greatly exaggerated   For more than a decade, people have been saying that the era of US dominance is coming to an end. But in reality there are still no other global players to rival it  In recent years, the idea that the United States is an empire in decline has gained considerable support, some of it from quarters that until very recently would have denied it was ever an empire at all. The New York Times, for instance, has run columns that describe a “remarkably benign” American empire that is “in retreat”, or even at risk of decline and fall.  Yet the shadow American power still casts over the rest of the world is unmistakable. The US has military superiority over all other countries, control of the world’s oceans via critical sea lanes, garrisons on every continent, a network of alliances that covers much of the industrial world, the ability to render individuals to secret prisons in countries from Cuba to Thailand, preponderant influence over the global financial system, about 30% of the world’s wealth and a continental economy not dependent on international trade.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: The US is the major power of the world, and we are still in a uni-polar world. But the trend line is clear. U.S. power is in decline, and we will be living in a multi-polar world in the next few years. I give it another 5 to 10 years.

The situation remains tense as Israel addresses security concerns and continues military operations to secure the release of hostages.  ( 53 min )

    US officials to visit Pakistan in December for consultations on various issues including the ongoing situation in Afghanistan; both countries exchanging visits to speed up the process; Pakistan blames Afghanistan for terrorist attacks and usage of Afghan oil for attacks; recent attack resulted in casualties; Pakistan deporting illegal Afghan citizens; US Assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration to visit Pakistan; discussions not limited to Afghanistan concerns.  ( 50 min )
    Israel bombs Gaza as pressure mounts to protect civilians
    Israel struck Gaza targets in its war on Hamas. The civilian death toll increased, causing international concern. More than 15,500 people have been killed in the Palestinian territory. Israeli air and artillery strikes hit Gaza, while rockets were launched from Gaza into Israel. The UN reported 160 Palestinian deaths in two incidents. The Israeli army said it had carried out 10,000 air strikes, located more than 800 shafts to Hamas tunnels destroyed 500 Hamas tunnels.  ( 66 min )
    Far-right parties eye gains in next year's EU parliament elections
    European far-right parties gathered in Italy to strategize for the upcoming European Parliament elections. They aim to reshape the European Union by adopting tougher immigration policies and relaxing climate regulations to safeguard jobs and industry. The meeting was inspired by Geert Wilders' PVV party's unexpected success in the recent Dutch elections. Italian Deputy Prime Minister Salvini, the host, aspires for their alliance to become the third-largest group in the EU Parliament.  ( 52 min )
    Italy refuses Munich museum's request to return ancient Roman statue bought by Adolf Hitler
    Italy's culture minister rejects the German State Antiquities Collection's request to return the Discobolus Palombara, a 2nd-century Roman copy of a Greek bronze statue that embodied Hitler's Aryan aesthetic. Hitler acquired the statue in 1938 against the wishes of Italian officials. The statue was returned to Italy in 1948. The dispute now involves the director of the National Roman Museum requesting the return of the statue's marble base from the German museum.  ( 48 min )
    After visiting Israel and Ramallah, the ICC prosecutor says he will intensify investigations
    The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC), Karim Khan, announced that the ICC will intensify investigations into possible crimes committed by Hamas and Israeli forces. The ICC has been looking into crimes in the Palestinian territories since 2021, but has not yet filed any charges. Khan witnessed "scenes of calculated cruelty" during his visit to locations of the October 7 attacks by Hamas. He called for the release of hostages taken by Hamas.  ( 56 min )
    Guinea-Bissau's leader calls a shootout an attempted coup, heightening tensions in West Africa
    Guinea-Bissau's President Umaro Sissoco Embalo confirmed that the recent shootout in the capital was an attempted coup, following the improper release of two ministers detained over corruption allegations. President Embalo dismissed the head of the National Guard and warned of consequences for everyone involved. This attempted coup adds to the growing number of military takeovers in West and Central Africa. The incident has garnered deep concern from the regional economic bloc.  ( 55 min )
    Man stabs four to death in New York's Queens, police shoot him dead
    A man wielding a steak knife killed four members of his extended family in Queens, New York City. The incident was reported by a girl in the Far Rockaway neighborhood. The suspect, a 38-year-old, stabbed two police officers who responded to the scene, but was shot dead by one of the officers. The suspect had a history of domestic violence. The police had to wait for the fire department to arrive before entering the home, as the suspect had set fire to a couch.  ( 47 min )
    Lula in Berlin for first Brazil-Germany talks in eight years
    Brazilian President Lula da Silva visits Berlin for Brazilian-German government consultations to revive ties after years of diplomatic isolation. Lula aims to restore Brazil's global standing after his predecessor Jair Bolsonaro. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, the first foreign leader to visit Lula, seeks to improve ties with the Global South. Both countries push for a quick trade deal between the EU and Mercosur. The visit highlights their differences over the Israel-Hamas war.  ( 52 min )
    US Commerce chief Gina Raimondo warns against China 'threat'
    US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo urges lawmakers, Silicon Valley, and US allies to prevent China from acquiring semiconductors and cutting-edge technologies crucial for national security. Raimondo emphasizes that China is the biggest threat, stating that they are not a friend. She highlights the role of her department in the fierce rivalry. Raimondo calls for tighter export controls, better funding to protect America's leadership in artificial intelligence and advanced semiconductor design.  ( 51 min )
    Belarus leader Alexander Lukashenko visits China to meet Xi Jinping
    Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko, a staunch ally of Moscow, is visiting China on Sunday and Monday to meet his counterpart Xi Jinping, the Belarusian presidency said. On Monday, he will hold talks with Xi on issues including "trade, the economy, investment and international cooperation", the presidency announced on Sunday.  ( 45 min )
    Kyiv says Russian forces shot surrendering Ukrainian soldiers
    Ukrainian officials accuse Russian forces of killing surrendering Ukrainian soldiers. It will be a war crime if confirmed. Video footage shows two uniformed men being shot at close range after surrendering. Ukrainian General Prosecutor's Office launches criminal investigation. Kyiv accuses Moscow of breaching international humanitarian law since the invasion of Ukraine. Ukrainian energy ministry reports power outages in towns and villages due to wintry weather and ongoing fighting.  ( 55 min )
    India agrees to withdraw soldiers from Maldives: President Muizzu
    India agrees to withdraw soldiers from the Maldives as President Mohamed Muizzu announces the decision. Muizzu campaigned to change the Maldives's 'India first' policy and remove the small Indian military presence. Indian government agreed to remove soldiers and establish a committee for development projects. Indian military personnel were mainly present to operate helicopters and aircraft, assist in disaster response, and help build a naval dockyard.  ( 49 min )
    Heavy snow in northern England causes havoc on highways and knocks out power
    Heavy snow in northern England caused motorists to be stranded in their cars and resulted in power outages for over 2,500 customers. Trucks blocked highways, leaving drivers stuck and in need of emergency assistance. The Lake District community of Ambleside experienced severe weather conditions, resembling an Alpine ski resort. Emergency services, including the Cumbria Fire & Rescue Service and Cumbria Police, worked tirelessly to rescue stranded travelers.  ( 52 min )
    Indian Sikh pilgrim dies due to cardiac arrest in Pakistan's Punjab province
    An Indian Sikh pilgrim in his 70s died in Lahore due to cardiac arrest. The body was handed over to the BSF at Wagah border. Another Sikh family was looted by robbers in police uniforms during Guru Nanak Dev's birth anniversary festivities in Lahore. Punjab's caretaker CM Mohsin Naqvi ordered the police to arrest the culprits within 48 hours, but no progress has been made in the case. Naqvi had ordered the Punjab police to arrest the culprits within 48 hours.  ( 48 min )
    Magnitude 6.6 aftershock causes panic in southern Philippines
    A magnitude 6.6 earthquake, followed by several strong aftershocks, hit Mindanao island, Philippines, triggering a tsunami alert. The earthquake occurred near Hinatuan municipality, the same area affected by a magnitude 7.6 quake the night before. Two people were killed in Bislig City and Tagum city, and several others were injured. There were no major damages reported, but cracked roads in Bislig City were observed. The earthquake also caused small swells in Japan's eastern Pacific coast.  ( 54 min )
    Hikers evacuated as Indonesia volcano spews ash tower
    Mount Marapi, an active volcano in western Indonesia, erupted on Sunday, spewing a three-kilometer column of ash into the sky. Dozens of hikers were evacuated from the area. The volcano, with a peak of 2,891 meters, is on the third-highest alert level in Indonesia. Authorities have imposed an exclusion zone around the crater. While there are no immediate reports of damage or casualties, 42 hikers are currently unaccounted for. Efforts are underway to ensure their safety and evacuation of others.  ( 50 min )

    Donald Trump mocks Joe Biden’s gaffes in Iowa speech
    Former US President Donald Trump took a jab at Joe Biden during an address in Ankeny, Iowa. Mr Trump said he is “very glad” he didn’t get any notes for his speech as he proceeded to mimic the US President struggling to read a prompt. “Here is Biden: ‘thank you... thank you...’,” Mr Trump said. This comes ahead of the state’s presidential caucuses in January as Mr Trump took to the campaign trail. Republicans in Iowa are expected to endorse the former president as their candidate to take on Joe Biden next November.

    Australia joins renewable energy pledge at COP28
    There has been optimism and progress on the third day of COP28. Australia has joined more than 100 countries at the United Nations Climate Summit pledging to triple global renewable energy generation capacity by 2030. If it is honoured, this pledge could deliver three quarters of the emissions cut needed to get to net zero. Energy Minister Chris Bowen has attended the meeting, backing renewables as the “cleanest and cheapest form of energy". "Australia has the resources and the smarts to help supply the world with clean energy technologies to drive down those emissions while spurring new Australian industry."
    Defence heads meet in California for second pillar of AUKUS
    The second pillar of the AUKUS alliance has been unveiled in California. Australia, the United Kingdom and the US will share a range of emerging military technology – including advanced artificial intelligence, to counter aggression from China. Defence Minister Richard Marles met with US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin and UK Defence Secretary Grant Shapps on Friday (local time) to announce the second pillar in the AUKUS alliance. The announcement included autonomous technology involving the deployment of AI on spy planes and sonobuoys to detect China’s submarines in the water. The three AUKUS are confident that this partnership can last the test of time and elections.

    North Korea begins reconnaissance satellite operations -KCNA
    North Korea's reconnaissance satellite operation office, functioning as a military intelligence organisation, started its mission on Saturday. The office, located at the Pyongyang General Control Centre of the National Aerospace Technology Administration (NATA), will report acquired information to the reconnaissance bureau at the army and other major units. Despite no released imagery, analysts and foreign governments debate its capability. South Korea also launched its own spy satellite this month.  ( 48 min )

Nikhil "Nick" Gupta was charged on Wednesday after an Indian government employee who works on security and intelligence encouraged him to take out a Sikh activist who supports a sovereign state in northern India, the Department of Justice said. The defendant conspired from India to assassinate, right here in New York City, a U.S. citizen of Indian origin who has publicly advocated for the establishment of a sovereign state for Sikhs," said Manhattan prosecutor Damian Williams in a statement. It's the second such incident announced in the past week. According to President Joe Biden's administration, investigators foiled another plot to kill a Sikh separatist in the United States. Among the most startling details in the Justice Department's statement is an alleged revelation from Gupta to an undercover DEA agent that another Sikh leader, Hardeep Singh Nijjar, "was also the target." In fact, he revealed, "We have so many targets." ALSO READ: You might think the NFL is racist. An insider says he’s about to prove it in court.     Release of Israeli teenage hostage ends mystery over lost dog
    Ever since Hamas's deadly October 7 attack on southern Israel, the father of 17-year-old hostage Mia Leimberg had been praying for her safe release from captivity in Gaza -- and the return of the family pet. To Moshe Leimberg's great joy, his daughter was finally freed on Tuesday as part of a group of hostages 12 -- 10 Israelis and two Thais -- that also included her mother and aunt. And the release of the hostages under an agreement to pause fighting between Israel and Hamas also solved the mystery of what happened to Mia's pet dog Bella. At the time of the Palestinian militant group's attack, the dog had been with Mia on the southern Israeli kibbutz of Nir Yitzhak, where she and her mother Gabriela had been visiting her aunt. Leimberg searched for the fluffy white dog in the aftermath of the assault -- in which around 240 hostages were taken, Israeli officials say -- hoping it would be a comfort for his daughter when she finally returned, Israeli daily Israel Hayom reported. The fate of the animal became clear on Tuesday when pictures were beamed around the world of Mia -- flanked by masked and armed fighters from Hamas and militant group the Islamic Jihad -- being handed over to Red Cross officials. She was carrying Bella in her arms, which it now appears was with her all along. Israeli officials say the Hamas attack on October 7 killed around 1,200 people, most of them civilians. In response, Israel has vowed to eliminate Hamas and has unleashed an air and ground campaign that the Hamas government says has killed more than 15,000 people, also mostly civilians. © 2023 AFP  ( 42 min )

    Breathless pope delegates reading as flu persists
    Pope Francis presided over his weekly audience Wednesday despite the flu that caused him to scrap a trip to Dubai, but asked an aide to deliver his reading for him. The Argentine pontiff, 86, looked tired and sounded breathless as he told the audience at the Vatican that "I'm still not well with this flu". Francis, who had part of a lung removed when he was younger, was forced Tuesday to cancel his scheduled trip to key UN climate talks, following advice from his doctors. The pope had been due to travel to Dubai from Friday to Sunday, but is suffering from an inflammation of the respiratory tract, Vatican spokesman Matteo Bruni said. Francis spoke at the end of Wednesday's audience to call for an end to the wars in Gaza and Ukraine, wheezing as he did so. But he looked cheered by a circus performance put on for him, complete with acrobats on roller skates. And before the general audience he told visiting members of the Celtic football club that he was feeling "better than yesterday". The pope, who turns 87 next month, has suffered a series of health issues in recent years, from knee and hip pain to an inflamed colon and most recently, hernia surgery in June. He was also hospitalized for three nights in March with bronchitis, which was cured with antibiotics. On Saturday, he cancelled events due to what the Vatican called "light flu symptoms". It said that a CT scan had ruled out "risks of pulmonary complications" and Francis was receiving antibiotics intravenously. © 2023 AFP  ( 42 min )

    Trump finally pins the blame on Putin in new bid to stay out of jail
    For years, former President Donald Trump has avoided agreeing with intelligence assessments that Russian President Vladimir Putin interfered on his behalf during the 2016 presidential election. Most infamously, Trump rejected the American intelligence community's assessment about Russia's actions at a press conference in Helsinki, Finland where he stood next to Putin and said, "President Putin says it's not Russia, I don't see any reason why it would be." But it seems that Trump will actually blame Putin for 2016 election interference if doing so will help keep him out of prison. Politico's Kyle Cheney flags a legal filing by Trump's attorneys this week in which they dispute special counsel Jack Smith's claims that Trump has damaged Americans' faith in the electoral system by essentially arguing that Putin did it first. "The Special Counsel's Office falsely alleges that President Trump 'eroded public faith in the administration of the election,'" the filing states. "The 2016 [Intelligence Community Assessment] uses strikingly similar language to attribute the origins of that erosion to foreign influence -- that is, foreign efforts to 'undermine public faith in the U.S. democratic process.'" The filing went on to argue that "President Trump is entitled to the detailed information supporting the conclusions in the 2016 Election ICA... in order to demonstrate to a jury that he did not create or cause the environment that the prosecution seeks to blame him for." What Trump's lawyers leave out is the fact that Trump openly encouraged Russia to hack political rival Hillary Clinton's email server and release her private communications. When Russia eventually leaked hacked emails from Clinton's campaign to WikiLeaks, Trump eagerly promoted them while on the campaign trail as evidence of Clinton's purported corruption.  ( 43 min )

    Paris mayor quits X, calling social media platform a 'vast global sewer'
    Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo said on Monday she was quitting Elon Musk's social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, which she described as a "global sewer" and a tool to disrupt democracy. "I've made the decision to leave X," Hidalgo said in an op-ed in French newspaper Le Monde. "X has in recent years become a weapon of mass destruction of our democracies", she wrote. The 64-year-old Socialist, who unsuccessfully stood for the presidency in 2022, joined Twitter as it was then known in 2009 and has been a frequent user of the platform. She accused X of promoting "misinformation", "anti-Semitism and racism." "The list of abuses is endless", she added. "This media has become a vast global sewer." Since Musk took over Twitter in 2022, a number of high-profile figures said they were leaving the popular social platform, but there has been no mass exodus. Several politicians including EU industry chief Thierry Breton have announced that they are opening accounts on competing networks in addition to maintaining their presence on X. The City of Paris account will remain on X, the mayor's office told AFP. By contrast, some organisations have taken the plunge, including the US public radio network NPR, or the German anti-discrimination agency. Hidalgo has regularly faced personal attacks on social media including Twitter, as well as sometimes criticism over the lack of cleanliness and security in Paris. (AFP)  ( 53 min )

The flight will leave London's Heathrow airport at 1130 GMT bound for New York's JFK. It is the first time that SAF will be used "in both engines, by a commercial airline, for long-haul flight", the airline said in a statement. However, the Boeing 787 plane equipped with Rolls-Royce engines will not carry any paying passengers or cargo. SAFs are produced from renewable biomass and waste resources and can be used in jet fuel to a maximum of 50 percent, having been blended with kerosene, in modern aircraft.     New book taps into the cultural history of eyeliner
    For centuries, eyeliner has been seen as a staple, and often the only beauty item some women and men wear. In culture journalist Zahra Hankir's latest book, "Eyeliner: A Cultural History," readers learn how eyeliner isn't just some superficial beauty hack and that in many cultures around the world, it has been revolutionized and popularized by people of color for medicinal purposes, authority and its cultural ties.

    On Tuesday, Ukraine is celebrating 10 years since the start of the Maidan Revolution, the uprising that led to the downfall of the pro-Russian government and closer ties with the European Union. It also sparked a new wave of aggression from neighboring Russia that led to its full-scale invasion nearly two years ago.

There are still thousands of quilombos across Brazil, and many continue to fight for their land and their rights.

In mid-March, the ICC issued arrest warrants for Putin and Maria Lvova-Belova, the Russian presidential commissioner for children’s rights over the Ukraine war.  ( 76 min )

    Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?
    Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated. Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…  ( 10 min )
    10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
    Getty Images How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…  ( 15 min )

    Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live
    Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth. In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters. The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…  ( 12 min )

Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call.     Why retailers are bullish on New York's luxury hallways
    Midtown is booming, brokers say, thanks to the return of office workers and tourists. “We are totally back,” said Steven Soutendijk, executive managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. Retailers around Midtown office corridors “live and die with office density, and we’re seeing a noticeable difference,” said David LaPierre, vice president of CBRE.
